title: 111_s961
content: The Act titled "Authorizing the Regulation of Swaps Act" repeals the prohibition on certain regulation of swap agreements. The Act titled "Authorizing the Regulation of Swaps Act" repeals various sections of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act and the Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934. The Act "Authorizing the Regulation of Swaps Act" repeals sections of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act and Securities Acts of 1933 and 1934, including sections related to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Commodity Futures Modernization Act of 2000, Legal Certainty for Bank Products Act of 2000, and Commodity Exchange Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF REGULATION AND OVERSIGHT REGARDING SWAP AGREEMENTS. Federal financial regulators are authorized to oversee and regulate swap agreements entered into by financial institutions or persons under their jurisdiction. They can also issue regulations, orders, and requirements related to these agreements. Federal financial regulators have oversight over swap agreements entered into by financial institutions or persons under their jurisdiction, including exchanges and trading facilities regulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has oversight over swap agreements traded on exchanges or clearing agencies, while the Securities and Exchange Commission regulates trading facilities and registered entities. This Act clarifies the regulatory responsibilities of each agency. The Act does not limit Federal financial regulators' authority over swap agreements. It does not impact the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's authority or require swap agreements to be traded on designated platforms. Prior to taking action under subsection (a)(2), Federal financial regulators must consult and cooperate with each other to ensure consistent treatment of swap agreements traded through registered exchanges or brokers under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this Act, a Federal financial regulator includes various federal agencies such as the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve, the National Credit Union Administration, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Office of Thrift Supervision, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and other relevant federal agencies. The term "swap agreement" refers to any agreement between eligible contract participants involving the execution, termination, assignment, exchange, or conveyance of rights or obligations under a swap agreement. This definition is relevant for federal agencies authorized to regulate financial institutions or financial instruments. Eligible contract participants can engage in swap agreements involving individual negotiation of material terms, excluding price and quantity, for options related to various financial interests or properties. Eligible contract participants can engage in swap agreements involving the exchange of payments based on various financial interests or properties. Eligible contract participants can engage in swap agreements that transfer financial risk associated with future changes in value without conveying ownership interest in an asset. This includes various types of swaps such as interest rate swaps, rate floors, rate caps, rate collars, cross-currency rate swaps, basis swaps, and currency swaps. A swap agreement involves the exchange of financial risks related to various assets or commodities, either fixed or contingent, and can include different types of swaps like currency swaps, equity swaps, credit default swaps, and commodity swaps. The term "swap agreement" excludes certain types of agreements. A swap agreement excludes certain types of agreements involving securities, options, or foreign currency on national securities exchanges. Any agreement, contract, or transaction involving the purchase or sale of securities on a contingent basis, unless based on a bona fide contingency affecting creditworthiness. This includes notes, bonds, or evidence of indebtedness that are securities, as well as agreements based on securities. A swap agreement is a contract entered into by the issuer of a security to raise capital, unless it is for managing a risk associated with capital raising. This includes a master agreement that provides for a swap agreement. The term "security" in this context refers to the definition in the Securities Act of 1933 or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The term "security" refers to the definition in the Securities Act of 1933 or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (15 U.S.C. 77b(a)(1) or 78c(a)(10)). SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to replace "security-based swap agreement" with "swap agreement" in various sections. The Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to replace "security-based swap agreement" with "swap agreement" in various sections, including section 10(b) and section 16(a)(2)(C). The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to remove references to exempt board of trades and specific sections within the Act. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to remove specific sections and references to exempt board of trades. Amendments include striking certain subsections and inserting new ones. The Commodity Exchange Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Improvement Act are amended to remove references to specific subsections and exempt board of trades. Amendments involve striking certain subsections and inserting new ones.
